questions.question: Which of the following factors affects pathloss?

explanations.a: Antenna height affects the line-of-sight and Fresnel zone clearance, impacting pathloss.
explanations.b: Increasing the distance generally increases pathloss due to spreading loss.
explanations.c: Higher carrier frequencies typically experience greater pathloss.

questions.question: Which of the following can cause shadowing?

explanations.a: Buildings can block or reflect radio signals, causing shadowing.
explanations.d: All listed objects can cause shadowing.

answers.a: Increases it in a predictable way
answers.b: Causes random variations in received signal strength
answers.c: Decreases it in a random way
answers.d: Causes a fixed reduction in signal power

explanations.a: Shadowing is not predictable like free-space loss.
explanations.b: Shadowing causes random fluctuations in received power due to environmental obstructions.
explanations.c: It does not consistently decrease pathloss.
explanations.d: It does not cause a fixed attenuation.

questions.question: Which frequency band would likely experience lower pathloss over the same distance?

explanations.a: Lower frequencies like 700 MHz generally suffer less pathloss over the same distance.
explanations.b: Higher frequencies experience greater free-space pathloss.
explanations.d: Very high frequencies suffer significant attenuation.

questions.question: If the transmit power is 50 dBm and the received power is 40 dBm, what is the pathloss in dB?

explanations.a: Pathloss = Tx power - Rx power = 50 - 40 = 10 dB.
explanations.b: This would be true if the received power were -40 dBm, not 40 dBm.
explanations.d: Pathloss cannot be negative in this case.

questions.question: In free-space conditions, pathloss increases approximately with:

answers.a: The square of the distance between transmitter and receiver
answers.b: The square root of the distance
answers.d: It does not depend on distance

explanations.a: Free-space loss follows the inverse-square law.
explanations.b: Square root is too slow a rate for free-space loss.
explanations.c: Cube of the distance is too steep for free-space loss.

questions.question: In urban environments, compared to rural environments, pathloss is generally:

explanations.a: While reflections can help in some cases, obstructions dominate in urban areas.
explanations.b: Obstructions such as buildings increase pathloss in urban areas.
explanations.d: Pathloss depends heavily on the environment.

questions.question: Why is the decibel (dB) scale commonly used to represent pathloss and signal strength?

answers.a: It makes the numbers larger and easier to read
answers.b: It allows multiplicative gains and losses to be handled via simple addition and subtraction
answers.c: It is a linear scale that represents absolute power levels
answers.d: It eliminates the need for complex mathematical models

explanations.a: The scale actually compresses large ranges of values into smaller, manageable numbers.
explanations.b: Logarithmic scales convert multiplication of power ratios into addition of dB values, simplifying link budget analysis.
explanations.c: The dB scale is logarithmic, not linear.
explanations.d: Mathematical models are still required; the scale just changes how values are represented.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the difference between large-scale fading and small-scale fading?

answers.a: Large-scale fading occurs over long distances; small-scale fading occurs over very short distances (wavelength scale)
answers.b: Large-scale fading is due to multipath; small-scale fading is due to pathloss
answers.c: There is no physical difference; the terms are interchangeable
answers.d: Small-scale fading describes the average signal power over a large area

explanations.a: Large-scale fading (pathloss and shadowing) represents mean signal change over distance, while small-scale fading involves rapid fluctuations due to multipath interference.
explanations.b: This is reversed; multipath causes small-scale fading.
explanations.c: They represent different physical phenomena and statistical models.
explanations.d: That is the definition of large-scale fading.
